title: How to Make Hash Brown Egg Nests

methods.name: Making Basic Hash Brown Egg Nests

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 400°F (205°C).
steps.description:
Generously grease a 12-well muffin tin with cooking spray, then set them aside. If you don't have any cooking spray, you can use cooking oil or butter instead. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/Make-Hash-Brown-Egg-Nests-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/Make-Hash-Brown-Egg-Nests-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Bake the potatoes for 45 to 60 minutes.
steps.description: Place the potatoes onto a baking sheet, then slide the baking sheet into the oven. Allow the potatoes to bake until they are tender. This will take about 45 to 60 minutes.

steps.headline: Peel, grate, and season the potatoes.
steps.description: Once the potatoes are baked, take them out of the oven and let them cool enough so that you can handle them. Peel the skin off, then grate them using a grater. Season the potatoes with a little bit of salt and pepper. Save time by preheating your oven to 425°F (219°C) while you prep the potatoes.

steps.headline: Spoon the potatoes into the muffin wells.
steps.description: Use you finders to spread the potatoes against the bottom and sides of each well to form a nest shape. You will need 3 to 4 tablespoons (60 to 80 grams) of grated potato for each muffin well. Make sure that the well in each nest is big enough to hold an egg.

steps.headline: Spray the nests with more cooking oil.
steps.description: If you don't have cooking spray, you can lightly brush the top of each nest with a little oil instead.

steps.headline: Bake nests for 15 to 20 minutes at 425°F (219°C).
steps.description: If you have not already, raise the temperature in your oven to 425°F (219°C). Once the oven reaches the correct temperature, put the muffin tin back inside the oven. Let the nests bake for 15 to 20 minutes. Keep a close eye on them and don't let them burn. You will continue cooking them in a moment.

steps.headline: Crack an egg into each nest.
steps.description: The egg should sit neatly in the wells you made earlier. Sprinkle the nests with more salt and pepper. If you want to, you can add some extras, such as herbs or sautéed vegetables.

steps.headline: Bake the nests for 15 more minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when the whites are set.

steps.headline: Let the nests cool slightly before you serve them.
steps.description: After about 5 minutes, pop them out of the muffin tin, and transfer them to a plate. Serve them while they are still warm. If you are having trouble removing the egg nests from the tin, run a knife around the edges of the nest first, then pop it out with a fork.

methods.name: Making Gourmet Hash Brown Egg Nests

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 425°F (219°C).
steps.description: Grease a 12-well muffin tin, then set it aside.

steps.headline: Break apart the hash browns into a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Thaw the hash browns first, then use your fingers to break them apart into a bowl. If you don't have hash browns, cook 3 to 4 potatoes first. Let them cool off, then peel and shred them.

steps.headline: Add the salt, pepper, olive oil, and 1 cup (100 grams) of cheese.
steps.description: Stir everything together well with a spoon. Be careful not to mash the hash browns too much, however; you want them to retain their shredded texture.

steps.headline: Scoop the hash brown mixture into the muffin tin.
steps.description: Use a tablespoon to distribute the hash brown mixture into each muffin well; you will need about 3 to 4 spoonfuls for each well. Next, use your fingers to press the mixture against the bottom and sides of each well, forming a nest-like shape. The nest needs to be big enough to hold an egg.

steps.headline: Bake the hash browns for about 15 minutes.
steps.description: You are ready for the next step when the cheese melts and the hash browns turn crispy on the edges. Save time by frying the bacon while the hash browns are baking. Let the bacon drain on a paper towel so that it's extra-crispy.

steps.headline: Crack an egg into each muffin well.
steps.description: Once the baking time is up, pull the hash brown nests out of the oven. Crack open an egg into each well. Save time by reducing the oven temperature to 350°F (177°C). This will give it time to reach the right temperature as you finish preparing the nests.

steps.headline: Add the rest of the cheese, bacon, and parsley.
steps.description: Sprinkle the remaining ½ cup (50 grams) of cheese over each egg. Crumple or chop the bacon up, then add it to each nest. Top the nests off with chopped, fresh parsley. If you want to, season them further with some salt and pepper.

steps.headline: Bake the nests at 350°F (177°C) for 13 to 16 minutes.
steps.description: If you have not yet already, reduce the oven temperature to 350°F (177°C). Once the oven reaches the right temperature, put the muffin tin back into the oven. Bake the nests for 13 to 16 minutes. They are ready when the egg whites set.

steps.headline: Let the nests cool slightly before you serve them.
steps.description: After about 5 minutes, run a knife around the outside of each nest. Use a fork to pop the nests out and transfer them to a plate. Serve them while they are still warm.

text:
Making Basic Hash Brown Egg Nests Preheat your oven to 400°F (205°C). Generously grease a 12-well muffin tin with cooking spray, then set them aside. If you don't have any cooking spray, you can use cooking oil or butter instead. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/Make-Hash-Brown-Egg-Nests-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/Make-Hash-Brown-Egg-Nests-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Bake the potatoes for 45 to 60 minutes. Place the potatoes onto a baking sheet, then slide the baking sheet into the oven. Allow the potatoes to bake until they are tender. This will take about 45 to 60 minutes. Peel, grate, and season the potatoes. Once the potatoes are baked, take them out of the oven and let them cool enough so that you can handle them. Peel the skin off, then grate them using a grater. Season the potatoes with a little bit of salt and pepper. Save time by preheating your oven to 425°F (219°C) while you prep the potatoes. Spoon the potatoes into the muffin wells. Use you finders to spread the potatoes against the bottom and sides of each well to form a nest shape. You will need 3 to 4 tablespoons (60 to 80 grams) of grated potato for each muffin well. Make sure that the well in each nest is big enough to hold an egg. Spray the nests with more cooking oil. If you don't have cooking spray, you can lightly brush the top of each nest with a little oil instead. Bake nests for 15 to 20 minutes at 425°F (219°C). If you have not already, raise the temperature in your oven to 425°F (219°C). Once the oven reaches the correct temperature, put the muffin tin back inside the oven. Let the nests bake for 15 to 20 minutes. Keep a close eye on them and don't let them burn. You will continue cooking them in a moment. Crack an egg into each nest. The egg should sit neatly in the wells you made earlier. Sprinkle the nests with more salt and pepper. If you want to, you can add some extras, such as herbs or sautéed vegetables. Bake the nests for 15 more minutes. They are ready when the whites are set. Let the nests cool slightly before you serve them. After about 5 minutes, pop them out of the muffin tin, and transfer them to a plate. Serve them while they are still warm. If you are having trouble removing the egg nests from the tin, run a knife around the edges of the nest first, then pop it out with a fork. Making Gourmet Hash Brown Egg Nests Preheat your oven to 425°F (219°C). Grease a 12-well muffin tin, then set it aside. Break apart the hash browns into a large mixing bowl. Thaw the hash browns first, then use your fingers to break them apart into a bowl. If you don't have hash browns, cook 3 to 4 potatoes first. Let them cool off, then peel and shred them. Add the salt, pepper, olive oil, and 1 cup (100 grams) of cheese. Stir everything together well with a spoon. Be careful not to mash the hash browns too much, however; you want them to retain their shredded texture. Scoop the hash brown mixture into the muffin tin. Use a tablespoon to distribute the hash brown mixture into each muffin well; you will need about 3 to 4 spoonfuls for each well. Next, use your fingers to press the mixture against the bottom and sides of each well, forming a nest-like shape. The nest needs to be big enough to hold an egg. Bake the hash browns for about 15 minutes. You are ready for the next step when the cheese melts and the hash browns turn crispy on the edges. Save time by frying the bacon while the hash browns are baking. Let the bacon drain on a paper towel so that it's extra-crispy. Crack an egg into each muffin well. Once the baking time is up, pull the hash brown nests out of the oven. Crack open an egg into each well. Save time by reducing the oven temperature to 350°F (177°C). This will give it time to reach the right temperature as you finish preparing the nests. Add the rest of the cheese, bacon, and parsley. Sprinkle the remaining ½ cup (50 grams) of cheese over each egg. Crumple or chop the bacon up, then add it to each nest. Top the nests off with chopped, fresh parsley. If you want to, season them further with some salt and pepper. Bake the nests at 350°F (177°C) for 13 to 16 minutes. If you have not yet already, reduce the oven temperature to 350°F (177°C). Once the oven reaches the right temperature, put the muffin tin back into the oven. Bake the nests for 13 to 16 minutes. They are ready when the egg whites set. Let the nests cool slightly before you serve them. After about 5 minutes, run a knife around the outside of each nest. Use a fork to pop the nests out and transfer them to a plate. Serve them while they are still warm.
sentences: Making Basic Hash Brown Egg Nests Preheat your oven to 400°F (205°C).
Generously grease a 12-well muffin tin with cooking spray, then set them aside.
If you don't have any cooking spray, you can use cooking oil or butter instead.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/Make-Hash-Brown-Egg-Nests-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/Make-Hash-Brown-Egg-Nests-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Bake the potatoes for 45 to 60 minutes.
Place the potatoes onto a baking sheet, then slide the baking sheet into the oven.
Allow the potatoes to bake until they are tender.
This will take about 45 to 60 minutes.
Peel, grate, and season the potatoes.
Once the potatoes are baked, take them out of the oven and let them cool enough so that you can handle them.
Peel the skin off, then grate them using a grater.
Season the potatoes with a little bit of salt and pepper.
Save time by preheating your oven to 425°F (219°C) while you prep the potatoes.
Spoon the potatoes into the muffin wells.
Use you finders to spread the potatoes against the bottom and sides of each well to form a nest shape.
You will need 3 to 4 tablespoons (60 to 80 grams) of grated potato for each muffin well.
Make sure that the well in each nest is big enough to hold an egg.
Spray the nests with more cooking oil.
If you don't have cooking spray, you can lightly brush the top of each nest with a little oil instead.
Bake nests for 15 to 20 minutes at 425°F (219°C).
If you have not already, raise the temperature in your oven to 425°F (219°C).
Once the oven reaches the correct temperature, put the muffin tin back inside the oven.
Let the nests bake for 15 to 20 minutes.
Keep a close eye on them and don't let them burn.
You will continue cooking them in a moment.
Crack an egg into each nest.
The egg should sit neatly in the wells you made earlier.
Sprinkle the nests with more salt and pepper.
If you want to, you can add some extras, such as herbs or sautéed vegetables.
Bake the nests for 15 more minutes.
They are ready when the whites are set.
Let the nests cool slightly before you serve them.
After about 5 minutes, pop them out of the muffin tin, and transfer them to a plate.
Serve them while they are still warm.
If you are having trouble removing the egg nests from the tin, run a knife around the edges of the nest first, then pop it out with a fork.
Making Gourmet Hash Brown Egg Nests Preheat your oven to 425°F (219°C).
Grease a 12-well muffin tin, then set it aside.
Break apart the hash browns into a large mixing bowl.
Thaw the hash browns first, then use your fingers to break them apart into a bowl.
If you don't have hash browns, cook 3 to 4 potatoes first.
Let them cool off, then peel and shred them.
Add the salt, pepper, olive oil, and 1 cup (100 grams) of cheese.
Stir everything together well with a spoon.
Be careful not to mash the hash browns too much, however; you want them to retain their shredded texture.
Scoop the hash brown mixture into the muffin tin.
Use a tablespoon to distribute the hash brown mixture into each muffin well; you will need about 3 to 4 spoonfuls for each well.
Next, use your fingers to press the mixture against the bottom and sides of each well, forming a nest-like shape.
The nest needs to be big enough to hold an egg.
Bake the hash browns for about 15 minutes.
You are ready for the next step when the cheese melts and the hash browns turn crispy on the edges.
Save time by frying the bacon while the hash browns are baking.
Let the bacon drain on a paper towel so that it's extra-crispy.
Crack an egg into each muffin well.
Once the baking time is up, pull the hash brown nests out of the oven.
Crack open an egg into each well.
Save time by reducing the oven temperature to 350°F (177°C).
This will give it time to reach the right temperature as you finish preparing the nests.
Add the rest of the cheese, bacon, and parsley.
Sprinkle the remaining ½ cup (50 grams) of cheese over each egg.
Crumple or chop the bacon up, then add it to each nest.
Top the nests off with chopped, fresh parsley.
If you want to, season them further with some salt and pepper.
Bake the nests at 350°F (177°C) for 13 to 16 minutes.
If you have not yet already, reduce the oven temperature to 350°F (177°C).
Once the oven reaches the right temperature, put the muffin tin back into the oven.
Bake the nests for 13 to 16 minutes.
They are ready when the egg whites set.
Let the nests cool slightly before you serve them.
After about 5 minutes, run a knife around the outside of each nest.
Use a fork to pop the nests out and transfer them to a plate.
Serve them while they are still warm.
